linkTarget.anchoringText: It is speculated that the ROZ was originally a portion of a larger oil entrapment, but the oil was displaced by water influx over geological time resulting in remaining oil saturations of up to 40% in some areas (Harouaka et al. 2013). The peculiarity of the ROZ, however, is that the remaining trapped and immobile oil becomes mobile only upon contact with miscible CO2 or depressurization. The amount of oil, if recovered can be a significant contribution to the economics of the production operations. Fig. 1 shows a typical saturation-depth profile from the San Andres Limestone of the Permian Basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Typical water saturation profile of the San Andres Limestone, Permian Basin, Texas, USA (after Brown 2001).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical water saturation profile of the San Andres Limestone, Permian Basin, Texas, USA (after Brown 2001).

linkTarget.bib:
Brown, 2001
A. Brown
2001. Effects of Hydrodynamics on Cenozoic Oil Migration, Wasson Field Area, Northwestern Shelf of the Permian Basin. West Texas Geological Society Fall Symposium 01-110: 133 142 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The East Seminole Field covers approximately 2,000 acres in Gaines County, Texas, USA and includes both the East Seminole San Andres Unit (ESSAU) and the Lindoss Unit. The field lies on the northeastern edge of the Central Basin Platform (Fig. 2a) and produces from a succession of anticlinal traps in the San Andres dolomite. Core data revealed that the bulk of the San Andres reservoir rock contains subtidal fusulinid pack/grainstones and intertidal pelleted wacke/packstones in a shallowing upward sequence.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: (a) Paleogeographic location map of the East Seminole Field in the Central Basin Platform of the Permian Basin, Texas, USA (after Merrill et al 2015). (b) East Seminole Field structure map of the oil/water contact with locations identified for the ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and the ESSAU 56W (after Gray 1989) courtesy of Tabula Rasa Energy.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Paleogeographic location map of the East Seminole Field in the Central Basin Platform of the Permian Basin, Texas, USA (after Merrill et al 2015). (b) East Seminole Field structure map of the oil/water contact with locations identified for the ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and the ESSAU 56W (after Gray 1989) courtesy of Tabula Rasa Energy.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Paleogeographic location map of the East Seminole Field in the Central Basin Platform of the Permian Basin, Texas, USA (after Merrill et al 2015)
East Seminole Field structure map of the oil/water contact with locations identified for the ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and the ESSAU 56W (after Gray 1989) courtesy of Tabula Rasa Energy

linkTarget.anchoringText: In fields that have been waterflooded, such as the East Seminole Field, resistivity responses became increasingly difficult to interpret as the mixing of the injected and formation water altered the water salinity. This results in difficulties with distinguishing the MP from the ROZ and in unreliable fluid saturation calculations. In fact, resistivity log responses RD, RS, and RMML from the wells studied showed no significant difference between the MP and ROZ and remained between 20 and100 ohm-meters (Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Digitized well log responses in tracks 1-4 for well ESSAU 70. Track 5 displays the 25%, 50%, and 75% probabilities of the ROS from the unpressurized core data. The probabilities were calculated as described in Methodology and Results.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Digitized well log responses in tracks 1-4 for well ESSAU 70. Track 5 displays the 25%, 50%, and 75% probabilities of the ROS from the unpressurized core data. The probabilities were calculated as described in Methodology and Results.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the result of 10,000 random sampling from the distributions of these ratios at each core depth, the values of most likely (median) and lower (25%) and upper (75%) quartiles of oil saturation ratios were determined. Simulated ratios were later converted to oil saturations for each depth. As an example, Fig.4 shows the predicted percentile distributions and the histograms of simulated oil-water saturation ratios at 5,510 ft (MP) and 5,550 ft (ROZ) for the Essau 70 well. Fig. 5 shows the ROS, as a function of depth, for the Essau 70 well at different uncertainty levels, as well as the scale-up estimations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Results of random sampling from the ESSAU 70 at 5510 feet in the MP and at 5550 feet in the ROZ Percentile Distribution - Essau #70 5510 ft - MP Histogram - Essau #70 5510 ft - MP Percentile Distribution - Essau #70 5550 ft - ROZ Histogram - Essau # 705550 ft - ROZ

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results of random sampling from the ESSAU 70 at 5510 feet in the MP and at 5550 feet in the ROZ Percentile Distribution - Essau #70 5510 ft - MP Histogram - Essau #70 5510 ft - MP Percentile Distribution - Essau #70 5550 ft - ROZ Histogram - Essau # 705550 ft - ROZ

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the result of 10,000 random sampling from the distributions of these ratios at each core depth, the values of most likely (median) and lower (25%) and upper (75%) quartiles of oil saturation ratios were determined. Simulated ratios were later converted to oil saturations for each depth. As an example, Fig.4 shows the predicted percentile distributions and the histograms of simulated oil-water saturation ratios at 5,510 ft (MP) and 5,550 ft (ROZ) for the Essau 70 well. Fig. 5 shows the ROS, as a function of depth, for the Essau 70 well at different uncertainty levels, as well as the scale-up estimations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of ROS using unpressured core samples from well bore ESSAU 70. The 50% (median) saturations used in this study follow closely with the scale-up saturations and both fall within the maximum So and minimum So limits.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of ROS using unpressured core samples from well bore ESSAU 70. The 50% (median) saturations used in this study follow closely with the scale-up saturations and both fall within the maximum So and minimum So limits.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results showed that 30 processing elements in the first hidden layer produced the lowest MSEs of 0.06288 for training. Next, the number of processing elements in the second hidden layer was varied between 23 and 27, while the number of processing elements in the first hidden layer was set to 30. The minimum MSE was 0.05938 for training, with 25 processing elements in the second hidden layer. Fig. 6 shows the sensitivity of the network to different number of hidden-layer processing elements.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Network performance in terms of training MSE with different number of hidden-layer processing elements.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Network performance in terms of training MSE with different number of hidden-layer processing elements.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To further test the network and to measure the relative importance of the inputs of the ANN model on output performance, a sensitivity analysis about the mean of each of the inputs was carried out. This analysis demonstrates how the model output varies in response to variation of an input. During this analysis, the inputs were varied around their mean by adding and subtracting one standard deviation, while keeping all other inputs at their respective mean values. The output was computed for 50 steps greater than and less than the mean value of the varied input. The results of the test are shown in Table 3 and in Fig. 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: A graphical representation of sensitivities of output response of the network to variations in inputs from 3 wells, ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and ESSAU 56W. The sensitivity axis is truncated at 0.5 to be able to show smaller values. The ranges of sensitivities are shown in Table 3.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A graphical representation of sensitivities of output response of the network to variations in inputs from 3 wells, ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and ESSAU 56W. The sensitivity axis is truncated at 0.5 to be able to show smaller values. The ranges of sensitivities are shown in Table 3.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 8 compares the target oil saturations in the testing and training data set with the predicted values. The comparison of the target data with the predicted values in these figures show that the performance of the network in predicting ROS is reasonable despite the large variations in the data. As expected, predicted values for the training data are in better agreement with the target values with a Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.87 and MSE of 34.6. The minimum and maximum absolute errors with training data set were 0.02% and 19.8%, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Target and predicted in-situ remaining oil saturation in MP and ROZ using testing (left) and training (right) data sets from 3 wells, ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and ESSAU 56W.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Target and predicted in-situ remaining oil saturation in MP and ROZ using testing (left) and training (right) data sets from 3 wells, ESSAU 70, Lindoss 31, and ESSAU 56W.
